sentence: International Business Machines has the appearance of a great value investment following its third-quarter disappointment.
It trades at just 8.5 times next year's expected earnings, has a dividend yield of 2.5%, aggressively buys back stock, and has Warren Buffett as an investor.
However, there's more to finding a good value stock than these noted metrics.
Underlying strength of a business must be present, which is why IBM is nothing more than a good value trap.
IBM is an enormous enterprise technology company selling software, hardware, and services.
With $22.4 billion in third-quarter revenue across multiple segments, it's difficult for many to wrap their minds around the size of this company.
However, in forming the discussion of why IBM is far from a value investment, one chart really says it all.

In looking at IBM's most recent quarter, some investors have voiced opinions that the company's 4% year-over-year revenue decline is not that bad, especially given the 16% stock losses accrued during the last month.
However, IBM's 4% loss during this last quarter is not just a one-time event, but rather comes on top of a 4% and 5% decline in the two years prior.
IBM has watched $2.35 billion in third-quarter revenue disappear during the last two years -- not including the lost revenue from 2012's year-over-year losses -- a significant amount of money.
This fact builds the foundation for IBM's lack of value because, in order for IBM to present a good investment opportunity, there must be light at the end of its dark revenue-losing tunnel.
But at this point, no end's in sight, and the rate of such declines are relatively in-line with previous years and quarters.
In looking at IBM's business as a whole, poor hardware and server sales have been consistent throughout its decline .
These two segments combined account for roughly 25% of total sales, and have consistently experienced double-digit sales declines.

The third quarter of 2014 was no different, as its Systems and Technology segment, or hardware, saw a 15% decline in sales, while revenue in its server products like Power Systems and Mainframe servers declined 10% and 35%, respectively.
That said, IBM's x86 servers business was recently sold to Lenovo.
Therefore, hardware declines are nothing new.
What's more alarming is IBM's newfound struggles in services.
This is a segment that accounts for more than 60% of IBM's total revenue.
IBM separates its services revenue into two units, technology and business, which both saw a 3% decline in revenue year over year.
These year-over-year losses were more significant than the 1% and 2% losses in technology and business, respectively, during the second quarter.
While alarming, these losses hardly compare to the 7% year-over-year decline that IBM's services backlog experienced in the quarter, far worse than the 1% decline in the second quarter.

While its services backlog is still large at $128 billion, this rapid decline serves as an indication of future revenue that IBM will report, meaning accelerated losses are likely part of Big Blue's future.
IBM's recent history hasn't looked good.
Last November, a Barclays analyst explained that every dollar earned by the cloud is multiple dollars lost for on-premise IT companies like IBM.
Given IBM's core business in IT, the rise of cloud services that perform IT and related services has become a nightmare that seemingly won't end.
IBM has hedged its business by making big investments in the cloud during the last two years.
In 2013, IBM acquired 10 companies, mostly related to the cloud, spending $3.1 billion.
Therefore, many investors point to the fact that IBM's cloud services revenue increased 80% year over year, and is now on a $3.1 billion annual run rate.

However, there are two things for investors to consider: Much of IBM's year-over-year growth was acquired through acquisitions rather than organic, and $3.1 billion in revenue is not enough to move the needle for IBM.
In fact, cloud services revenue is about 5% of IBM's total.

While the cloud services industry has created $13.5 billion in revenue during the last 12 months, growing 50% annually, according to Synergy Research, IBM would need to own the entire market for its revenue in this segment to have an effect on its broader business.
Unfortunately, IBM is not even close to owning this space, lagging Amazon.com and Microsoft and competing with Google and Salesforce for third place.
With cloud services growing fast, IBM is losing a lot of dollars in revenue throughout its business, unable to counter the rate of loss with its growing cloud segment.
IBM may buy back stock, it may pay a good dividend, and its stock may appear cheap to the naked eye, but there's more to investing in value stocks than simply identifying such metrics.
There must be a strong underlying business, one that's at least stable so that the noted metrics remain in place.
With IBM's revenue declining by the quarter, and showing no signs of improvement, and its gross margin declining 90 basis points year over year, IBM is far from stable.
With such declines, valuation multiples such as P/E ratio naturally fail to reflect the underlying business.
Given the state of IBM's business, the company is likely trading at fair value.
If its business continues to worsen, then the stock will likely fall further.
In retrospect, no value remains.
